section.title: Faith Cometh By Hearing the Word of God

chapter.line: Given the importance of translating all of the Scriptures accurately into all of the languages
And the sheer size of the Scriptures in their entirety
We conclude that translations should target hypothetical “average” languages; hypothetical kiones
W. V. O. Quine’s ”indeterminacy of meaning” essentially reveals the centrally-crucial role of faith in all cross-cultural communication
Armed with the creeds—with faith—we know what doctrine rises off the pages of Scripture, no matter what the language; we know the Message of the messages, and the Word of whom the words speak
Hypothetical koines are either inevitable in making the translation, or necessarily consequent (non-hypothetical) after a translation

Conscious hypothetical koines are more-preferable, and they may contain intentional borrowings (such as Hebraisms and Hellenisms) to preserve accuracy and nuance; liturgical languages are the commonest example (e.g.; KJV English for many of us today)
The dialectal strategy: consistent verb forms
